Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: We have three patients that appear Patient with age 45 M Patient with age 62 F and Patient with age 28 M But note Events might have same age gender but could be different patients Since age and gender alone are not unique but in a small log likely they correspond to distinct cases However there is also department some events are in ER some in Surgery etc But a single patient might move between departments

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The 45M patient is primarily in ER and Radiology 62F in ER and Laboratory 28M in Surgery and also some activities like Doctor consultation in Surgery event 6 and later in ER Actually event 6 is Doctor consultation in Surgery for 28M which fits

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Case A 45M events 1 4 7 12 15 Case B 62F events 2 5 8 10 11 14 17 Case C 28M events 3 6 9 13 16 18

Name: Validation - PE
Text: 5 events 62F 7 events 28M 6 events That sums to 5 7 6 18 Good

Name: Validation - PE
Text: doublecheck if any event might belong to a different case For example event 6 is Doctor consultation in Surgery for 28M with reason scheduled knee surgery That fits the surgical case Event 9 Surgery preparation in Surgery for 28M Event 13 Surgery performed Event 16 Recovery room Event 18 Discharge from Surgery So that case is coherent

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - PE
Text: Could there be more than three cases For example could there be a case where a patient moves from ER to Surgery Possibly 45M had a fracture and might need surgery but in the log 45M is discharged from ER with followup outpatient clinic not surgery 28M registered in Surgery department not ER so separate

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: One might also note that there is a Doctor Lee who appears for both 28M event6 and event13 and for 45M event12 Thats okay same doctor can treat multiple patients Also Dr Smith appears for 62F event8 11 14 and maybe elsewhere Not for others So consistent
